ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CAPITAL ASSISTANCE SCHEME
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what are the criteria for grants under the Capital Assistance Scheme; and if he will outline the general activities of those companies which have been given assistance under the Scheme.

Column: 1176



     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Capital Assistance Scheme was established in 1975 to provide financial assistance to manufacturing companies with specialised projects that can bring economic and technological benefit to Singapore. Under the Scheme, the investor can obtain equity and/or loan capital for its project in Singapore. The Scheme does not provide cash grant.

    Applications are considered on a case-by-case basis but the projects must satisfy the following general criteria:

Column: 1177



    (a) utilise and promote skills and be technologically desirable, or could play an important role in developing essential supporting industries which may be lacking in Singapore; and

    (b) have experienced difficulty for one reason or another in raising equity capital or in obtaining loans from commercial sources.

    Companies which have been granted assistance under the Scheme include those manufacturing:

    Components for constant speed drives for jet engines

    Engineering plastic components

    Precision lathes

    Ferrous castings

    Gears for aircraft engines

    Automatic lathes

    Overhaul and repair of hot sections of aircraft engines

    Colour television picture tubes.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, could the Minister give the number of companies, local as well as foreign, which were given grants under the Capital Assistance Scheme?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, during this period, loans were granted to 16 companies, 10 of which were wholly-owned foreign companies, and the remainder were joint ventures which include Singaporean interests.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia: Sir, a lot of our manufacturers complained about the too stringent and bureaucratic procedures adopted in processing applications for loans under the Capital Assistance Scheme. Would the Minister like to comment on this, and whether he would ask the EDB to review its procedures for application for grants under the Capital Assistance Scheme?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, two criteria have been cited just now. The question is whether we should be liberal in giving out finances under the Scheme when we are fairly confident that some of the com-

Column: 1178

panies would not be able to return the loans given or to give a return on the equity capital. A certain amount of prudence would, therefore, have to be exercised by the officials in charge to ensure that public funds, whilst being given out to aid industries, are not wasted on projects which do not in their view have a chance to succeed.

Column: 1178

MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY
(Joint ventures with foreign investors)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Trade and Industry how many local companies have set up joint ventures with foreign investors in the manufacturing industry, year by year, since 1970, giving the types of joint venture; and how many of these joint ventures were initiated by the Economic Development Board.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the figures for 1970 and 1971. However, I could give him figures from 1972 onwards. The reason is that EDB started compiling these figures only from 1972.

    Between 1972 and 1979, 244 companies were set up as joint ventures between foreign investors and local entrepreneurs. The investment committed by these companies amounted to S$1.3 billion. All these joint venture companies were promoted and serviced by EDB. The list of these projects is not exhaustive as the EDB does not have information on joint ventures which were formed outside the EDB, that is, those which were not promoted or serviced by the EDB.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, has the Minister any information how many of these joint ventures were successful?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would not be able to give him the exact figure. But I have here a table (Cols. 1233 - 1234) which, in fact, should have been given in the first part of my answer to the Member for Ang Mo Kio. The table gives the figures from 1972 to 1979 on a year by year and industry by industry basis.

Column: 1179

It will, however, be too tedious for me to read out the figures together with the quantum of investment per year. I shall hand a copy to the Member for Ang Mo Kio and have this appended to my statement. The figures here would give an indication of the success of the companies involved. For example, if those companies that were formed in 1972 were still operating in 1979, they would be regarded as still in operation. I do not know the profits of these companies, so I would not use the word "success" but they are still in operation.

    Head Q -
2.38 p.m.

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff (Kolem Ayer): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead Code QA-03 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, while some of our youths drown themselves in the troubled waters of drug-taking - whether it be methaqualone, cannabis or narcotics; and some aping the latest craze of disco dancing - we are relieved to know that many of them still spend their leisure time in a more meaningful way, like learning the art of self-defence or martial arts.

    May I first congratulate the Hon. Minister for his Ministry's efforts which result in a lesser number of drug-takers. I would also like to congratulate those individuals and social and religious organisations like SANA, Muslim Council of Service (MCS) and the Volunteer Aftercare Officers (VAO's) for their valuable contributions.

Column: 1180



    A word of caution to those who introduced disco dancing to our institutions, like the community centre, especially to the conclusion made in the western countries, and that is:

    "Those who think that disco has nothing to do with drug-taking, illegal sex and permissiveness, they are socially myopic."

    Sir, we must clearly think and encourage more in terms of what our citizens will and can do during their leisure time. Every form of literary, artistic, aesthetic and physical activity (like martial arts) in which the self can be expressed in a creative and meaningful way must be encouraged. Martial art is an art where one could nurture the development of one's physical ability as well as one's mental capability. The former could be easily learned. But the latter needs every grain of correct and right guidance. This is where the role of the leader or instructor comes into the picture.

    There are three basic elements in order to be a good human being. Unlike my hon. Friend, the Member for Kim Seng who enlightened this august Chamber with his six commandments, I can only manage to impart three elements: They are: right thinking, right speaking and right doing.

    Be careful about what you do, be extra-careful about what you speak because these elements emanate from what you think. Even though only God knows what you think but a mere mortal could make his conclusion judging from what you say and do. This is the crux and the most difficult part of learning and teaching.

    But experience and age will help a great deal - they will be the essential factors. That is why I think the minimum age of an instructor should be 25 years with due respect to the exceptionally younger ones who mature faster and possess endurance and patience of a master. Sir, I would like to know the minimum age of instructors that the Hon. Minister has so far permitted or accepted.

    My second question is: will the Ministry register an instructor who has already been registered under one school of martial art but

Column: 1181

has now created a new one? With due respect to my colleague, the hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens who, we all know, is prominent in the art of Taekwondo, I would like to elaborate on this point by making a simple example without any offence intended.

    Let us say, a person has been registered as an instructor of Taekwondo. After learning another an for some time, say, Hapkido, he later on creates a combination of these two arts and calls it Taktido (because of the sleepless night to create it - he 'tak tidor' which means, he does not sleep). Would the Ministry register him as an instructor, knowing full well that there are at least three important possibilities?

    1. He may be a creative person.

    2. He may have quarrelled within his organisation and was a persona non grata.

    3. A fraud and a selfish, unethical person who changes a little bit here and there of the original art, creates a "new art" and a new school and makes money out of it.
2.45 p.m.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Sir, I will just answer the questions put by the Member for Kolam Ayer. I agree with what he said with regard to his three commandments.

    With regard to the minimum age for instructors, as far as the Martial Arts Control Unit of the Ministry of Home Affairs is concerned, they do not impose a minimum age for registration as instructors. Anyone wishing to be registered as an instructor must be of good character. That is the most important requirement. He must also possess a certificate of competency or testimonial of proficiency in the type of martial an he wishes to teach. This is issued by the chief instructor of the respective martial arts association or the controlling body of the martial art.

    I must say that the Martial Arts Control Unit has no expertise to evaluate the professional competence of the various types of martial art instructors. What we do is to consult the Singapore Sports Council on every application for registration of a martial arts

Column: 1182

instructor. We issue an instructor's certificate if the applicant is found to be competent to teach the form of martial art as stated in the certificate. In the majority of cases this is quite specific. However, in the past, the Martial Arts Control Unit had also issued certificates to martial arts instructors to teach mixed martial arts, that is to say, a combination of the various types of martial arts - Taekwondo, Karate, Thai boxing, and so on. I hope that answers the second part of his question.

    As regards a new form of martial art, as an example the Member referred to Taktido. I do not know what is meant by that. It could mean a new form of martial art in which the instructor does not sleep l But since we do not have such expertise, we will first investigate to see whether there is such an association and whether it is a respectable association. As far as competency is concerned, we shall refer it to the Singapore Sports Council.

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff: In view of the answer given by the Minister, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment by leave, withdrawn.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead Code QD-02 of the Development Estimates.

    Sir, in the Memorandum on the Budget, under "Development Estimates", it is explained that:

    'The provision of $1.55 million under the Crime Control Programme is for the construction of the Divisional Police Headquarters Stations at Napier Road and Jurong Town.'

I am surprised that there are no plans for the construction of the F Division that is now situated at the Paya Lebar Police Station. For the information of Members in this House, the F Division covers a very wide ares with a few constituencies under its charge. It stretches from Sembawang down to Tampines constituency. The population of this land area is also very large. Moreover,

Column: 1183

the Hou Kang New Town is being developed. Therefore, my question is: why are there no plans for the building of a Divisional Police Headquarters for F Division? It is not necessary that it should be in Punggol, but it must be centrally located.

     Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson): Thomson.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Yes, maybe in Thomson, if it pleases the Member for Thomson.

    I raised this matter with the previous Minister for Home Affairs many years ago, long before we have the present Minister for Home Affairs. Some kind of a promise was given that this matter would not only be looked into but a site had already been chosen for the F Division Police Head-quarters. But this has come to naught. And worst of all, the facilities at the Paya Lebar Police Station are inadequate. I must make it clear that the police officers in the Paya Lebar Police Station are not in cahoots with me in raising this issue in Parliament, I have visited the Paya Lebar Police Station many times and I am surprised to see that until seven months ago there was not even modern sanitation. There was only the bucket system. I have taken up this issue many years ago, at least ten years. With such conditions, surely the necessary facilities should be provided for the police officers. Although there have been some improvements to the Paya Lebar Police Station by way of renovations, nevertheless, I still feel that there must be plans in hand to build the F Division Police Headquarters somewhere in that area for the reasons that I have mentioned. As I said, there is a provision of $1.55 million for the Divisional Police Headquarters Stations at Napier Road and Jurong Town. This is needed, of course, but there is a greater need for an F Division Police Headquarters. I hope the Minister would not reply by merely saying, "We will consider it. We will draw up plans", but let us see that these plans come to fruition.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the views and sentiments expressed by the Member for Punggol with

Column: 1184

regard to the building of a new headquarters station for the F Division. But what I do not agree with him is his suggestion that there are no plans for building such a Divisional Headquarters for F Division. In fact, we have this plan to build a new headquarters police station for quite some time. We have, in fact, been implementing part of the plan.

    May I say that in 1976 we shifted the Rural West Divisional Headquarters temporarily from Bukit Panjang to Yung Loh Road in Jurong New Town because of a shift in population. We started to build the Jurong Headquarters Station as part of a plan to build a new divisional headquarters station. Since 1 5th March, 1980 the new Jurong Police Station at Corporation Road has been in operation. That is why I have not had any queries from the Member for Jurong.

    In 1977, we also built and completed the headquarters station for the B Division in the Toa Payoh New Town to replace the old police station at Kandang Kerbau.

    At the moment for the E Division (Orchard Road) a new headquarters station is being built at Napier Road. It is expected to be completed in October this year.

    As early as August 1976, my Ministry submitted to the Ministry of Finance a comprehensive plan on the redevelopment of four other existing police stations in the A, C, F and G Divisions. The proposal was that the Beach Road Police Station in C Division should be relocated at Aljunied Road; the Paya Lebar Police Station in F Division be moved to Ang Mo Kio New Town, and the Joo Chiat Police Station in G Division be shifted to Bedok New Town. Originally, my Ministry proposed that the Central Police Station in A Division should continue to remain at the former Police Headquarters at Eu Tong Sen Street. However, after consultation with the Urban Redevelopment Authority, we proposed to the Ministry of Finance to relocate the police station at Cantonment Road by 1984 to make way for urban redevelopment at the present Eu Tong Sen site.

Column: 1185



    In the plan submitted to the Ministry of Finance. in 1976, we also proposed the creation of two new Land divisions at Clementi New Town and Woodlands New Town, bringing the total number of police stations from the existing eight to ten. The Ministry of Finance raised a number of points on this plan for redevelopment of police stations and the creation of the two new Land divisions with the building of the new two divisional headquarters stations. Officials of my Ministry are still holding discussions on the matter, and I hope they can come to an amicable settlement that will satisfy the Member for Punggol.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, it is not a question of satisfying me at all. The Minister must satisfy the needs of the people. That is important. Coming down to his answers, I cannot accept them. First, he talked about the B Division. Why should the Kandang Kerbau Police Station be shifted? The reason is that it has got to make way for road widening at Rochore Canal. So it has got to give way. Secondly, in the case of the Geylang Police Station, it has got to be shifted because of the road widening, not because of a shift in population which is not the reason. I think hon. Members will see my side of the story.
3.00 p.m.

     Some hon. Members: Hear, hear!

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: As for Paya Lebar Police Station, Sir, the widening of Upper Serangoon Road has not gone that far as to necessitate the shift of the Station. When the Minister talks of Orchard Road Police Station, the answer is the same. Sir, it boils down to one thing. It is because of urban renewal, road or canal widening that police stations standing in the way have to be relocated. When they have to go, surely alternative sites must be found for them.

     Mr Ho See Beng: There is no credit.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: There is no credit at all. I fully agree with my good Friend, the hon. Member for Khe Bong. It is no use seeing part of the plan. The building of the F Divi-

Column: 1186

sional Headquarters was raised many years ago. I think the site was somewhere at the junction of Upper Thomson Road and Yio Chu Kang Road. I hope to get a satisfactory answer which will satisfy the needs of the people in the constituencies. I will name the constituencies. They are Sembawang, Nee Soon (which is having a new town), Thomson, Braddell Heights, Serangoon Gardens, Jalan Kayu, Upper Serangoon, Paya Lebar -

     An hon. Member: Punggol.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: And Punggol. So many constituencies are served by F Division, Sir. I understand that it was not until some seven months ago that the Paya Lebar Police Station was provided with modern sanitation facilities. So I hope to get something concrete from the Hon. Minister and he should not pass the buck just because the Hon. Minister for Finance is here.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Pass the bucket!

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: They can pass the bucket or whatever it is, I am not at all interested. What I am interested, Sir, is a new divisional police headquarters for F Division to be built as soon as possible. Let him not take years after new towns have come up and then say, "Oh, owing to a shift of population, the station has to be relocated." Please answer the question. How long did it take for Too Payoh Police Station to come up? Sir, may I repeat, unless I get a satisfactory answer, I will not withdraw my amendment.

     An hon. Member: Do not withdraw!

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, as my constituency has been referred to, I feel I must stand up to be counted on and to give moral support to the hon. Member for Punggol.

    The Hon. Minister mentioned that the proposal was submitted to the Ministry of Finance in 1976. This is 1980. I do not know what sort of dialogue is going on between the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Finance. It has taken four years and there is still nothing concrete.

Column: 1187



    The hon. Member for Punggol has omitted Ang Mo Kio. Ang Mo Kio New Town also comes under F Division. With so many hundreds of thousands of people moving into Ang Mo Kio, what the Ministry has done is to close down a very small police post at Yio Chu Kang Road and transfer the staff to Ang Mo Kio. And that is the strength and the facilities of the police force looking after Ang Mo Kio. I think it is shameful. Something ought to be done. The security of the people who have settled in the new town is important. I think they want a sense of security. We are not giving them that.

    I fully share the sentiments of the Member for Punggol. What we want is a positive answer. It is no use beating about the bush by referring to Jurong and so on. We are not interested. All that we are interested is: what are the plans for F Division, and give us a positive answer. Do not pass the buck to the Ministry of Finance, please.

     An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I correct a misconception on the part of the Member for Punggol? When I said that I hoped my answer would satisfy him, I was implying that if it could satisfy him, it must also satisfy his constituents. The fact that he has spoken eloquently on behalf of his constituents is an indication that he will only be satisfied if his constituents are satisfied.

    May I clarify? Divisional headquarters stations have been built in Toa Payoh and Jurong, and one is being built in Napier Road. These stations are not being built because of proposals for road widening. For example, shifting the headquarters station from Bukit Panjang, the former Rural West Divisional Headquarters station, to Jurong is not the result of a proposal for road widening. There is no such thing. These stations have been built because of a shift in population. We have to relocate them properly so that they can serve a congregation of populated areas.

    I do not disagree at all with the sentiments and the eloquent advocacy of the Member for

Column: 1188

Punggol and the Member for Jalan Kayu of the urgent need for divisional headquarters stations in four Police Divisions, including Paya Lebar. I am not passing the buck. I am glad that the Minister for Finance is here today to hear the eloquent advocacy of the Member for Punggol and the Member for Jalan Kayu for new divisional headquarters stations. And I support their sentiments.

    As far as the Ministry of Home Affairs is concerned, we will do our best to get these stations. As Members know, we cannot call for tenders unless we have the funds or we are permitted, like community centres, to raise funds. I am not passing the buck. I like to put forward the plain facts of life without having to enunciate another commandment. After all, commandments are now the fashion in this House. What I can say is that I appreciate the need for a new F Divisional Headquarters because the present headquarters station at Paya Lebar is out of the way and there is a dire need for it to be shifted to Ang Mo Kio where there is a growing concentration of population. Since we could not relocate the station in Ang Mo Kio New Town, at least we were able to set up a police post, although in the words of the Member for Jalan Kayu, "it is very inadequate." I agree with him that it is inadequate but at least we tried to do something in the meantime.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I am not only not convinced, I am also not satisfied with the replies of the Hon. Minister. As the hon. Member for Jalan Kayu rightly pointed out, the small police station along Yio Chu Kang Road was transferred to Ang Mo Kio. We know the place very well. What can the small police station at Ang Mo Kio do? Ang Mo Kio has hundreds of blocks of flats. What about the Hou Kang New Town? So it is not a question of understanding the feelings or sharing the sentiments. My question is: what plans has the Minister got? He has got no plans. It is not a question of having no funds. Is the Hon. Minister aware that if he were to go through the Hansard he will see that way back in the 70's. there were plans for the construction of the F Divisional Head-

Column: 1189

quarters. I would like to know what has come out of these plans?

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I quite sympathise with the Minister for Home Affairs. He says that he has got no money and he cannot raise money like raising money for the building of community centres. May I offer him a suggestion? Why does he not issue more martial art licences? Because martial art pugilists can help him contain the gangsters, and there may be a lot of gangsters in Punggol! If there are more martial art societies in Punggol, that may satisfy the Member for Punggol.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: On a point of clarification, Sir. In Punggol, the crime rate is very low, if not negligible. I am proud of Punggol. The Hon. Minister can bear me out on the crime rate in Punggol.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, the Hon. Minister in his reply said that he has been doing his best. So he is implying that somebody is not doing his best. Could he please tell us who is not doing his best? I think we should face up to the facts. It is no use going round and round saying, "We have initiated proposals four years back, and we have been talking to the Ministry of Finance." It is four years, not four months. So let us have the facts. Who is holding up the matter? Let us see what can be done. Can we not short-circuit the bureaucratic red-tape, or whatever it is, and come to a positive decision? One way or the other, please.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am indebted to the Member for Khe Bong for trying to side with me. I hope they will not accuse me of collusion with him. May I just clarify that even if I were to issue more martial art licences, the money collected will go to revenue. That means it goes to the Treasury. I am just stating a fact which I believe all Members know. All licence fees go to revenue.

    On the question of who is not doing his best, Members have got to take it from me that, as far as the Ministry of Home Affairs is concerned, we are doing our best. We have the plans. Since we have already built three

Column: 1190

divisional headquarters police stations, there is no difficulty in taking the same plans and make the necessary modifications to the plans for a new divisional headquarters station. Perhaps the Member does not know the financial procedure of Government. We cannot do anything in the way of commissioning an architect to draw up the building plans until we get approval from the Treasury. I hope my colleague, the Minister for Finance, will not think that I have plotted with both the Member for Punggol and the Member for Jalan Kayu to make such a strong advocacy for new headquarters stations. I hope he does not think so.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Far from it, Sir. I must put things in the right perspective. If there are no plans, how can he ask for money? That is the question. So where are his plans? That is another question. The Minister has not answered my question at all. He said he has got plans, but where are they?
3.15 p.m.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: I think the debate is getting to be a bit childish. What does the Member mean by "plans"? Does he mean architectural plans, or plans for delineation of the divisional boundaries, adding two more to make 10? Or does he mean plans for a new headquarters station? If he means architectural plans, we do not have the plans. But if he means delineation of boundaries and thus creating two more, and plans to build the headquarters stations, we have the plans. I cannot produce it right now, but if the Member could come to my Ministry I can show him the plans.

     An hon. Member: He has got no time.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: There are plans. In fact, the plans have been submitted to the Ministry of Finance. They are now being discussed. There have been some disagreements. As far as I am concerned, I do not quarrel with the Member's sentiments -
